columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the dilution.

The ROE is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{ROE }&=\dfrac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Total equity}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

First, let us compute the new price-earnings (PE) ratio of the company. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PE ratio}&=\dfrac{\text{Share price}}{\text{New EPS}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$75.00}}{\text{\$14.87}}\\[10pt]

&={\textbf{5.04}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The company's PE ratio is 5.04.**

To determine the ROE on the new investment, we need to compute the first additional net income. However, we cannot compute the new additional net income considering that the price after the offering has to be $75.00 per share. 

We must determine the earnings per share by using the share price computation. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

\
The company's data: 
| |Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|PE ratio | 5.04| 
|Share price| $75.00|

\
Thus,
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Share price}&={\text{EPS $\times$ PE ratio}}\\
\text{\$75.00}&={\text{EPS $\times$ 5.04}}\\
\text{\$75.00}&={\text{5.04EPS}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Then, let us divide both sides by 5.04 to cancel out the coefficient of EPS. This is done as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{\$75.00}&={\text{5.04EPS}}\\[10pt]
\dfrac{\text{5.04EPS}}{\text{5.04}}&=\dfrac{\text{\$75.00}}{\text{5.04}}\\[10pt]
{\textbf{EPS}}&={\text{\$14.88}}\\
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The company's EPS amounts to $14.88 if the share price remains constant.**

Then, we will compute the new number of shares from the investment cost. This is computed as follows: 
\
The company's data: 
| |Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Share price| $75.00| 
|Cost of investment| $1,500,000.00|

\
Thus,
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New shares}&=\dfrac{\text{Cost of investment}}{\text{Share price}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$1,500,000.00}}{\text{\$75.00}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{20,000 shares}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The new equity issuance will have an additional 20,000 shares.**

Next, let us multiply the EPs by the additional number of shares. This is to determine the amount of the additional net income. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Additional net income}&={\text{EPS $\times$ New shares}}\\

&={\text{\$14.88 $\times$ 20,000}}\\
&={\textbf{\$297,600.00}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The additional net income amounts to $297,600.00.**

Now, we will compute the net present value of the investment. This will assist us in determining the company's future earnings growth. This is computed as follows: 

The investment's net present value (NPV) equals the investment's cost plus the firm's new market value minus its current market value.


 $$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&={\text{-\$1.5 million+[\$75.00 $\times$(64,000 + 20,000)-(\$75.00 $\times$ 64000)] }}\\[5pt]
&={\textbf{\$0}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The NPV of the company investmentÂ is 0**. Since the company is investing in a 0 NPV investment, there is no market dilution.
